statement.tex: %text Prove that \[ \frac{4\sin\theta}{(2+\cos\theta)} - \theta\] is an increasing function in \[ \left[ 0,\frac\pi{2} \right] \] %

\\ \underline\text{Check our work} %text
The given function \[ f(\theta) = \frac{4\sin\theta}{(\cos\theta + 2)} - \theta\] is increasing in \[\left[0,\frac\pi{2}\right]\] \underline\text{because }$\ldots$ %

options.tex: %text No. $f(\theta)$ is increasing, but not strictly increasing in \[\left[ 0,\frac\pi{2}\right]\] because \[\frac{df}{d\theta} =0\] when $\theta = \frac\pi{2}$ %
%text Yes. $f(\theta)$ is strictly increasing in \[\left[ 0,\frac\pi{2}\right]\]. We know this because \[ \frac{df}{d\theta}\geq 0 \] when $\theta\in\left[0,\frac\pi{2} \right]$ %

reason.tex:
%text For a function to be \underline\text{strictly increasing} in an interval, $\dfrac{df}{d\theta}\gt 0$. Which means that $\dfrac{df}{d\theta}\neq 0$.
But for the given function - in the given interval - $\dfrac{df}{d\theta} = 0$ when $\theta=\frac\pi{2}$. Hence, while $f(\theta)$ is increasing, it is not strictly increasing. %
